Description: Percent accuracy of completing a task in the study.
Estimated age of first learning for a concept.
Estimates of ambiguity for a concept or information about different word meanings (i.e. number of meanings).
Estimates of strength of response to a concept.
Estimates of the relationship between concepts that are used together, often in free association format (i.e. the first word that pops to mind after a cue word has been listed).
Information related to lists of words all related to one cue word, such as bird, plant, animal.
The probability of an individual word completing a specific spot in a sentence.
Estimates of the intricacy or complicatedness of a concept.
Estimates of the non-abstractness of a concept, sometimes described as how touchable a concept is.
Probabilities of distinctiveness between pairs of concepts, or the likelihood those two concepts will be confused with each other (usually letters).
Contextual avaliability or contextual diversity, indicating how easy to remember or how many contexts a concept might appear in.
Estimates of how different, unique a concept seemed.
Estimates of how important or powerful a concept seemed.
Estimates of how difficult a concept was to remember.
Estimates of how well known a concept seemed.
The rates of occurrence for concepts.
The relationship between written and spoken symbols.
Estimates of the likelihood of remembering concepts.
Participant response times to real and pseudowords in a yes/no decision task.
Participant response times to reading aloud real and pseudowords.
Estimates of the similarity between images.
Estimates of the complexity of images.
Estimates of how easy or difficulty a concept is to imagine.
Estimates of the strength of a concept or how intense the concept seems.
Alphabetic characters.
Estimates of how meaningful or significant a concept seems.
The different ways or modes that something can be experiences (i.e. perceptual, tactile).
The structure of a concept's morphemes.
Estimates of the similarity between concepts.
The number of concepts that differ by one letter.
Type of speech for a concept (i.e. verbs, nouns).
A basic unit of sound in a language wherein changes bring changes to a word's meaning.
The number of concepts that differ by one phoneme.
The advantage in processing a concept receives when shown together with a related concept.
The way in which a concept is spoken.
The amount of time required to respond to a concept.
The likelihood of remembering a concept from memory.
The likelihood of recognizing (remembering) a concept from memory.
Concepts that have corresponding sounds.
Estimates of relationships between word pairs based on definition and meaning.
Studies that used different sensory mechanisms (tactile or visually presented) or had ratings of actions/animation of concepts.
Estimates of common conceptions that would complete a blank in sentence.
Estimations of the likeness or sameness between two concepts.
A unit of pronunciation with at least one vowel, dipthong, or consonant.
Information about the grammatical rules of a language.
Estimates of how common or normal a feature is for a concept.
Estimates of the strength of emotions or feelings for concepts.
Estimates of the intricacy or complicatedness of a picture.
Estimates of likelihoods of letter combinations that would complete a word.
